source.name: SQL Constraints
source.instructions:
Please select the correct answer and _Check it!_ to have your answer assessed. If you are wrong, you will see the correct answer highlighted:

__Select the list of that contains only valid SQL constraints:__

source.name: A simple blog database
source.instructions:
A `sql-5-7.sql` file has been opened for you. 

In the `sql-5-7.sql` file:

1. Use the `blog` database
1. Write a SQL `RIGHT OUTER JOIN` statement that _joins_ the `user_id` column from the `blog.posts` table, the `name` column of the `blog.users` table and the `body` column of the `blog.posts` table together.

---
Once you have completed these tasks press the _Check It!_ button to have your solution assessed.

source.name: Altering the comments table
source.instructions:
A `mysql` prompt has been opened for you. 

Using the `blog` database (use either a single-line or a multi-line SQL statement):

1. Write a SQL `ALTER TABLE` statement that adds a `post_id` column to the `blog.comments` table. 
This new column should be an `INTEGER` data type with a max. size of 3 digits, `UNSIGNED`, it should be `NOT NULL` and it should work as a `FOREIGN KEY` that uses as a reference the `id` column of the `blog.posts` table.

---
Once you have completed these tasks press the _Check It!_ button to have your solution assessed.

source.name: Altering tables to add foreign keys
source.instructions:
A `mysql` prompt has been opened for you. 

Using the `college` database (use either a single-line or a multi-line SQL statement):

1. Write a SQL `ALTER TABLE` statement that adds a `classroom_id` column to the `college.students` table. 
This new column should be an `INTEGER` data type with a max. size of 3 digits, `UNSIGNED`, it can be `NULL` and it should work as a `FOREIGN KEY` that uses as a reference the `id` column of the `college.classrooms` table.

---
Once you have completed these tasks press the _Check It!_ button to have your solution assessed.

source.name: SQL Left outer join
source.instructions:
A `sql-5-4.sql` file has been opened for you. 

In the `sql-5-4.sql` file:

1. Use the `college` database
1. Write a SQL `LEFT OUTER JOIN` statement that _joins_ the data from the `college.classrooms` table and the `college.courses` table together.

---
Once you have completed these tasks press the _Check It!_ button to have your solution assessed.

source.name: SQL JOIN
source.instructions:
A `sql-5-3.sql` file has been opened for you. 

In the `sql-5-3.sql` file:

1. Use the `college` database
1. Write a SQL `SELECT` statement that _joins_ the data from the `college.classrooms` table and the `college.courses` table together.

---
Once you have completed these tasks press the _Check It!_ button to have your solution assessed.

source.name: Defining the comments table
source.instructions:
A `mysql` prompt has been opened for you. 

Using the `blog` database, complete the following tasks:

1. Create a `comments` table with this definition (use either a single-line or a multi-line SQL statement):
```
+---------+-----------------+------+-----+---------+----------------+
| Field   | Type            | Null | Key | Default | Extra          |
+---------+-----------------+------+-----+---------+----------------+
| id      | int(3) unsigned | NO   | PRI | NULL    | auto_increment |
| body    | text            | YES  |     | NULL    |                |
| user_id | int(7) unsigned | NO   | MUL | NULL    |                |
+---------+-----------------+------+-----+---------+----------------+
```
---
Once you have completed these tasks press the _Check It!_ button to have your solution assessed.

source.name: Joining specific columns
source.instructions:
A `sql-5-6.sql` file has been opened for you. 

In the `sql-5-6.sql` file:

1. Use the `college` database
1. Write a SQL `LEFT OUTER JOIN` statement that _joins_ only the `course_id` column from the `college.classrooms` table and the `id` column of the `college.courses` table together.

---
Once you have completed these tasks press the _Check It!_ button to have your solution assessed.

source.name: Defining the reference table
source.instructions:
A `mysql` prompt has been opened for you. 

Using the `college` database, complete the following tasks (use either a single-line or a multi-line SQL statement):

1. Create a `courses` table with this definition (try using a multi-line SQL statement):
```
+---------+---------------------+------+-----+---------+----------------+
| Field   | Type                | Null | Key | Default | Extra          |
+---------+---------------------+------+-----+---------+----------------+
| id      | int(3) unsigned     | NO   | PRI | NULL    | auto_increment |
| title   | varchar(255)        | NO   | UNI | NULL    |                |
| credits | tinyint(2) unsigned | NO   |     | 1       |                |
+---------+---------------------+------+-----+---------+----------------+
```
---
Once you have completed these tasks press the _Check It!_ button to have your solution assessed.

source.name: Defining the foreign key
source.instructions:
A `mysql` prompt has been opened for you. 

Using the `college` database, complete the following tasks (use either a single-line or a multi-line SQL statement):

1. Create a `classrooms` table with this definition (try using a multi-line SQL statement):
```
+-----------+-----------------+------+-----+---------+----------------+
| Field     | Type            | Null | Key | Default | Extra          |
+-----------+-----------------+------+-----+---------+----------------+
| id        | int(3) unsigned | NO   | PRI | NULL    | auto_increment |
| room_num  | int(4) unsigned | NO   | UNI | NULL    |                |
| course_id | int(3) unsigned | YES  | MUL | NULL    |                |
+-----------+-----------------+------+-----+---------+----------------+
```
---
Once you have completed these tasks press the _Check It!_ button to have your solution assessed.

source.name: SQL right outer join
source.instructions:
A `sql-5-5.sql` file has been opened for you. 

In the `sql-5-5.sql` file:

1. Use the `college` database
1. Write a SQL `RIGHT OUTER JOIN` statement that _joins_ the data from the `college.classrooms` table and the `college.courses` table together.

---
Once you have completed these tasks press the _Check It!_ button to have your solution assessed.
